pageData.titleName2: Use of Selective and Differential Media

pageData.text: Samples obtained from nature are most often a mix of many types of microorganisms, which can be identified or isolated by several methods. One common method focuses on how different species grow on different types of media. Two major types of media used for identifying and isolating these microorganisms include , which allow growth of only certain types of organisms, and , which allow growth of closely-related organisms that will appear visibly different on the media due to their growth patterns. In this investigation, both types of media will be used to identify bacteria.

pageData.text: Microbial art is created on Petri dishes. Artists use pigmented microbes to “paint” shapes and scenes on agar plates. The American Society of Microbiology has an annual contest celebrating this art form, the ASM Agar Art Contest<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Artists must not only know what pigments each organism makes, but they must take care to understand the growth rates and nutrient requirements. If one organism grows too fast, it could take over the Petri dish and ruin the desired scene. Although this form of expression has become rather sophisticated and now uses many strains of transformed bacteria, Alexander Flemming is credited with inventing the art form.

Before Alexander Flemming became famous for the discovery of penicillin, he was an artist. As a member of the Chelsea Arts Club, Flemming painted with watercolors. It is not clear where the inspiration for creating microbial art came from, but Flemming used many different organisms to create different designs on Petri dishes such as fighting stick figures, ballerinas, houses, soldiers, mothers feeding children, and many other scenes<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>.

pageData.text: In research and healthcare, determining the species of microbes present in a mixed sample is often very important. Identifying the specific microbes can be done by stimulating the growth of a certain species while inhibiting growth of others. Media used to isolate microbes based on occurrence of growth are called <button class='glossary-text'>selective media</button>. Selective media are commonly used in two ways:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Selective growth</button> can be performed by adding certain nutrients that are more easily used by one type of microorganism than another. Thus, the organism capable of using these nutrients best will outperform and outgrow all others and become the dominant species in the medium.

occurs when a substance is added to the medium that inhibits the metabolism of a certain group of microorganisms but not another group. Selective inhibition is commonly used to screen for Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria. Bacteria have a cell wall made of peptidoglycan that is much thinner in Gram-negative bacteria, while Gram-positive bacteria have a multilayered peptidoglycan cell wall. The thicker cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria can trap substances between the cell membrane and the outer peptidoglycan layer and also protect the bacteria against attacks and harmful substances. Adding a particular substance, such as sodium azide, will inhibit growth of Gram-negative bacteria that do not have this same layer of protection. Growth of Gram-positive bacteria would not be significantly affected. On the other hand, non-synthetic enicillin inhibits Gram-positive bacteria because it targets peptidoglycan but has little effect on Gram-negative bacteria. Understanding which substance(s) can be used to inhibit certain groups of bacteria allows for effective treatment in a medical setting and accurate identification of bacteria present in a mixed sample.

pageData.text: In addition to selective media, another method used to distinguish between microorganisms uses dyes that can be easily seen before and after bacterial growth. Microorganisms growing on the medium will cause changes in the dye pattern; for instance, they can break down the dye, causing areas of clearing to appear and enabling easy detection of a certain type of microorganism. Microbial growth can also change the medium’s pH, leading to a color change if the dye present is a pH indicator. Media containing these dyes are called <button class='glossary-text'>differential media</button> and are often used for quality control in the food industry and as diagnostic tools in healthcare settings. Differential media can also allow observation of changes in growth patterns of the microorganisms. For example, a colony’s growth can be limited in response to the substance added, or the colony can spread out more rapidly because the substance promotes its growth.

Although selective and differential media can be used separately, these techniques are often used in conjunction. Many differential media can function as selective media and vice versa. For example, when the presence of Staphylococcus needs to be confirmed in a sample containing various types of bacteria, the following process can be used: because staphylococci are Gram-positive, one could first isolate them from Gram-negative bacteria using a selective medium containing sodium azide. Then, a differential medium called could be used to differentiate specific Staphylococcus from other Gram-positive bacteria present. Some species of Staphylococcus will create a yellow zone surrounding their colonies when grown on this type of agar, while other Gram-positive bacteria will not grow or will fail to generate this color change.

<button class='glossary-text'>Enriched media</button> are able to support the growth of many different organisms, including those with complex nutritional needs, which are said to be <button class='glossary-text'>fastidious</button>. Such organisms are often unable to grow on general-purpose media, such as nutrient agar. Blood is a common ingredient in enriched media, used to isolate and identify certain pathogenic (disease-causing) bacteria.

pageData.subTitle: Common Types of Media
pageData.text: Many common media can be used both for selective and differential screening of bacteria. The exact nature of the screening method is most often determined by the general composition of the microorganisms present in a culture, which influences the choice of media used.

text:
Mannitol Salt Agar (MSA)
As mentioned above, is often used to isolate Staphylococcus bacteria. This medium contains the sugar mannitol; 7.5% NaCl; and the pH indicator phenol red. Mannitol is a fermentable food source for some microorganisms but cannot be fermented by others. One product of this fermentation is an acid that lowers the pH of the medium, leading to a color change from red to yellow of the pH indicator present. This color demonstrates how MSA functions as a differential medium, as some bacteria will cause a yellow color due to mannitol fermentation but others will not (see Figure 1). The addition of 7.5% NaCl makes MSA a selective medium because not all microorganisms can withstand this level of salt. Only bacteria that can tolerate these salt levels will grow on MSA, while other bacteria will die. Thus, MSA selects for bacteria that can survive high salt levels and differentiates between bacteria that can ferment mannitol and those that cannot.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Close-up view of bacterial growth on mannitol salt agar, which is pink. The growth is yellow in color and is surrounded by a yellow halo.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Close-up view of bacterial growth on mannitol salt agar, which is pink. The growth is yellow in color and is surrounded by a yellow halo.

text:
MacConkey Agar (MAC)
This selective and differential medium is widely used in clinical settings to isolate typhoid-and dysentery-causing microorganisms and identify coliform bacteria, such as E. coli and Salmonella species. This agar selects against Gram-positive bacteria because it contains crystal violet and bile salts that cause the breakdown of the cell wall. As a differential agar, also contains the sugar lactose, and the pH indicator neutral red. Organisms that can ferment lactose will produce a bright pink color due a lowering of pH from acidic byproducts (see Figure 2, top). Gram-negative bacteria that do not ferment lactose will still grow on the medium but will appear colorless (see Figure 2, bottom) or brownish because no pH change has occurred.

pageData.disc: Figure 2: Close-up view of two different organisms growing on MacConkey agar, which is pink in color prior to the introduction of microorganisms. The top photo shows intensely pink growth, indicative of a lactose-fermenting organism, against the lighter pink agar. The bottom photo shows creamy-yellow growth; the agar has lost some of its pink color.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Close-up view of two different organisms growing on MacConkey agar, which is pink in color prior to the introduction of microorganisms. The top photo shows intensely pink growth, indicative of a lactose-fermenting organism, against the lighter pink agar. The bottom photo shows creamy-yellow growth; the agar has lost some of its pink color.

text:
Eosin Methylene Blue Agar (EMB)
This medium, also known as Levine agar, contains two dyes, eosin and methylene blue. It also includes the sugar lactose. The dyes inhibit growth of Gram-positive bacteria, so EMB is selective for Gram-negative bacteria. Species able to rapidly ferment lactose and produce certain acid byproducts will cause a significant drop in pH and cause the dyes in the agar to precipitate, leading to dark growth (see Figure 3, top), sometimes having a green metallic sheen when viewed from a slight angle. Weak lactose fermenters may appear a less intense purple with no sheen. Organisms that do not ferment lactose will appear colorless or the same color as the medium (see Figure 3, bottom). Thus, EMB helps differentiate between Gram-negative bacteria based on their ability to ferment lactose in the agar.

pageData.disc: Figure 3: Close-up view of two different organisms growing on dark, purplish-red eosin methylene blue agar. The top photo shows very dark blue-black growth with a metallic sheen on the surface, indicating a rapid lactose fermenter. The bottom photo shows colorless growth, which matches the color of the surrounding agar, indicative of a lactose non-fermenter.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Close-up view of two different organisms growing on dark, purplish-red eosin methylene blue agar. The top photo shows very dark blue-black growth with a metallic sheen on the surface, indicating a rapid lactose fermenter. The bottom photo shows colorless growth, which matches the color of the surrounding agar, indicative of a lactose non-fermenter.

pageData.text: Examples of species typically identified using EMB are coliform bacteria, such as E. coli, which rapidly ferment lactose, and Enterobacter species, which do not ferment lactose as strongly as E. coli.

text:
Blood Agar
As its name implies, this non-selective differential medium contains blood, typically from sheep. Erythrocytes, or red blood cells, contain hemoglobin, which gives blood its red color. Hemoglobin is protected by the erythrocyte cell membrane, but some microorganisms produce (secreted toxins) that can cause . Hemolysis describes the bursting, or lysis, of the erythrocyte that leads to the release of its contents. Hemoglobin will degrade outside the erythrocyte and lose its red color. Detection of hemolysis using can help identify Gram-positive bacteria based on the degree of hemolysis they cause (See Figure 4). Throat swabs are often applied to blood agar to test for the presence of the bacterium that causes strep throat.

No hemolysis: Exotoxins are not produced by some bacteria; thus, no hemolysis will occur. No change to the medium color will be observed, although bacterial growth will appear. Lack of hemolysis is sometimes called gamma hemolysis.

Alpha hemolysis: Describes partial lysis, in which not all the erythrocytes surrounding the microorganisms are destroyed. Partial lysis is observed as a green/yellow color surrounding the bacterial growth.

Beta hemolysis: Complete lysis of the erythrocytes surrounding the growth will occur. Zones of clearing will surround the growth, and the agar will become transparent where complete lysis has occurred. Beta hemolysis is produced by the strep throat bacterium group A Streptococcus.

pageData.disc: Figure 4: Close-up view of three different organisms growing on blood agar. The top photo shows white growth on bright red agar. No color change or clearing of the agar surrounds the growth, indicating lack of hemolysis. The middle photo shows white growth surrounded by deep greenish-yellow tinted agar, indicating partial hemolysis, known as alpha hemolysis. The bottom photo shows white growth surrounded by agar that has become transparent, indicating complete hemolysis, known as beta hemolysis.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Close-up view of three different organisms growing on blood agar. The top photo shows white growth on bright red agar. No color change or clearing of the agar surrounds the growth, indicating lack of hemolysis. The middle photo shows white growth surrounded by deep greenish-yellow tinted agar, indicating partial hemolysis, known as alpha hemolysis. The bottom photo shows white growth surrounded by agar that has become transparent, indicating complete hemolysis, known as beta hemolysis.

text:
Chocolate Agar
is a non-selective but differential enriched medium. Like , chocolate agar contains erythrocytes. However, these erythrocytes have already been lysed by slowly heating the medium to 80° C, giving it a “chocolate” brown color. This medium is produced, stored, and used in an environment without oxygen. Any growth on chocolate agar plates will appear as clearing of the surrounding area because the bacteria will break down and absorb released nutrients from the lysed erythrocytes. Chocolate agar is used to specifically isolate organisms. Bacteria commonly isolated on chocolate agar include Haemophilus influenza, which causes various respiratory infections and meningitis, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which causes the sexually-transmitted infection, gonorrhea. Chocolate agar can be made selective by the addition of antibacterials, such as bacitracin.

• Skip Preparation Steps 6–12, and proceed to the Activity.

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.

Retrieve the needed media and, if applicable, lyophilized culture, from storage. If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment kit. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older E. coli culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of broth from the reactivated E. coli culture to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth labeled “E. coli”.
Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then discard the loop in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 6 and 7 with the M. luteus and S. epidermidis cultures.
Extinguish the candle and empty the alcohol from the disposal jar as described in the Disposal and Cleanup section, but keep the jar for later use.

Incubate the inoculated broth tubes upright in the rack with their caps slightly loose. All three organisms will grow at room temperature; however, E. coli and S. epidermidis will grow faster around 37° C (99° F).
Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution, remove your PPE, and wash your hands thoroughly.

Allow between 2 and 4 days of incubation for the new cultures to grow. Do not proceed until all of the cultures are growing well. Be aware that M. luteus tends to grow a bit more slowly than the others.

pageData.text: Prepare to work as described in Steps 1–5.

Note: Wait until your culture is turbid before proceeding to Activity 1.
Both Micrococcus luteus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are non-motile and their growth will be along the bottom of the tube. You will want to make sure the cells are in suspension. Escherichia coli is motile and the growth should be throughout the culture medium so they will appear turbid though they will also have more growth along the bottom of the tube.

In Activity 1, you will divide the 3 <button class='glossary-text'>differential media</button> plates into 3 sections and inoculate each section of each plate with the appropriate bacterium. You will then observe growth, color, and appearance of the media after 48, 72 and 96 hours for each plate section.

Place each agar plate (<button class='glossary-text'>MSA</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>MAC</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>EMB</button>) inverted (turned upside down) on your work surface.

With the grease pencil or permanent marker, divide each plate into three equal sectors as illustrated in Figure 5. Make sure you draw on the outside of the bottom of the plate (not the lid) and that the markings can be clearly seen.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Diagram of an agar plate divided into three equal sectors.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram of an agar plate divided into three equal sectors.

pageData.text: Write the name of each bacterium in a sector of each plate. You can abbreviate as E. coli, S. epidermidis, and M. luteus. Then turn each plate right side up.

Begin by inoculating the MSA plate with E. coli. Aseptically obtain a loop of inoculum from the E. coli culture, and touch the loop gently to the surface of the agar only in the “E. coli” sector of the plate. Taking care not to gouge the agar, drag the loop back and forth over the surface of the agar in this section by following a zigzag pattern as shown in Figure 6. Make sure to spread the culture very thinly. Close the lid immediately afterward and set the MSA plate aside. Place the loop in the disposal jar.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Diagram of a hand holding an inoculation loop, which is being used to streak a loop of inoculum across one sector of the agar in a Petri dish.

pageData.text: Next, you will inoculate the MAC plate with E. coli. Aseptically obtain another loop of E. coli inoculum. Touch the loop gently to the surface of the agar only in the “E. coli” sector of the plate. Taking care not to gouge the agar, drag the loop back and forth over the surface of the agar in this sector by following a zigzag pattern as shown in Figure 6. Make sure to spread the culture very thinly. Close the lid immediately afterward and set the MAC plate aside. Place the loop in the disposal jar.

Now you will inoculate the EMB plate with E. coli. Aseptically obtain another loop of E. coli inoculum. Touch the loop gently to the surface of the agar only in the “E. coli” sector of the plate. Taking care not to gouge the agar, drag the loop back and forth over the surface of the agar in this sector by following a zigzag pattern as shown in Figure 6. Make sure to spread the culture very thinly. Close the lid immediately afterward and set the EMB plate aside. Place the inoculating loop in the disposal jar.

Repeat the inoculation procedures above for both M. luteus and S. epidermidis, inoculating the appropriate sectors of each plate with each organism. Be sure to use a new inoculating loop for each sector of each plate.
Invert all three plates (turn them upside-down), and set them aside for incubation.
Incubate the cultures for 48 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After 48 hours of incubation, record your observations in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3, describing the amount and color of growth, as well as the color and appearance of the agar immediately surrounding the growth. Take a photograph of the plate to document your cultures.Do not remove the lids when observing the plates and taking pictures. For better pictures, keep the plates inverted.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Observe and photograph the cultures again after 72 and 96 hours of incubation, noting your results in the data tables.
Note: Micrococcus luteus is fastidious and grows slowly at suboptimal conditions. If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to become significantly turbid.

To dispose of used inoculating loops, let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes. Then, while wearing PPE, pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running, and discard the loops in the garbage, wrapped in an opaque plastic bag. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.
Keep your broth cultures unless otherwise directed by your instructor.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution, open the tube or plate. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and then clean with soap and water. Always wear your PPE while disinfecting.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Close-up view of bacterial growth on mannitol salt agar, which is pink. The growth is yellow in color and is surrounded by a yellow halo.

pageData.content: Figure 2. Lactose fermenter and non-fermenter on MAC
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Close-up view of two different organisms growing on MacConkey agar, which is pink in color prior to the introduction of microorganisms. The top photo shows intensely pink growth, indicative of a lactose-fermenting organism, against the lighter pink agar. The bottom photo shows creamy-yellow growth; the agar has lost some of its pink color.

pageData.content: Figure 3. Rapid lactose fermenter and non-fermenter on EMB
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Close-up view of two different organisms growing on dark, purplish-red eosin methylene blue agar. The top photo shows very dark blue-black growth with a metallic sheen on the surface, indicating a rapid lactose fermenter. The bottom photo shows colorless growth, which matches the color of the surrounding agar, indicative of a lactose non-fermenter.

pageData.content: Figure 4. Degrees of hemolysis on blood agar
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Close-up view of three different organisms growing on blood agar. The top photo shows white growth on bright red agar. No color change or clearing of the agar surrounds the growth, indicating lack of hemolysis. The middle photo shows white growth surrounded by deep greenish-yellow tinted agar, indicating partial hemolysis, known as alpha hemolysis. The bottom photo shows white growth surrounded by agar that has become transparent, indicating complete hemolysis, known as beta hemolysis.

data.title: Blood agar
data.content: Non-selective, differential medium that contains blood

data.title: Chocolate agar
data.content: Non-selective, differential enriched medium that contains erthrocytes that have been lysed and heated

data.title: Differential media
data.content: Media that differentiates between microbes based on their biochemical properties, usually using dyes

data.title: Enriched media
data.content: Media that is able to support the growth of many different organisms, including fastidious organisms

data.title: Eosin methylene blue agar (EMB)
data.content: The selective and differential medium that contains eosin, methylene blue, and lactose; also called Levine EMB

data.title: Hemolysis
data.content: The bursting, or lysis, of red blood cells and the subsequent release of their contents

data.title: MacConkey agar (MAC)
data.content: The selective and differential medium that contains crystal violet, bile salts, lactose, and neutral red pH indicator

data.title: Mannitol salt agar (MSA)
data.content: The selective medium that contains mannitol, 7.5% sodium chloride (NaCl), and phenol red pH indicator

data.title: Selective growth
data.content: The selection strategy of selective media containing certain nutrients to encourage growth of certain groups of microorganisms

data.title: Selective inhibition
data.content: The selection strategy of selective media containing a substance to inhibit the growth of certain groups of microorganisms

data.title: Selective media
data.content: Media used to isolate microbes based on occurrence of growth
